Posts.Content: Hi Ceecee, My hair was thinning due to some other meds that I was on.  I started taking Biotin (10,000mcg - Incite Nutrition - Amazon) regularly a couple of months ago, and it has definitely helped (even my hairdresser commented on how much thicker it was).  It's about £10 for 200 tablets. Mags :-)
Posts.Title: Letrozole - hair thinning

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, It's definitely worth trying different brands if you don't think that the one you're currently on suits you. I started on the Cipla brand, and was in a lot of pain (I even considered stopping).  I changed to Sandoz and felt better even after a couple of days.  Some find that Sun Pharma suits them best.  It may be worth looking for the thread 'letrozole side effects' as there is quite a lot of info regarding people's experiences there. Mags :-) xx
Posts.Title: Letrozole - hair thinning

Posts.Content: Hi Von, It may be worth trying another brand (see the post 'Letrozole and side effects'), although from what I've read, Femara seems to be the best so far in terms of SEs.  Having said that, we're all different. I'm hoping to try the Sandoz brand (Cipla is a nightmare), but I won't know until I pick it up if it's the same as Femara ( as it's also made by Novartis). Quite a few ladies seem to get on with Sun Pharmaceuticals brand. I wish I could be of more help, but I'm new to this myself and I'm relying on extra pain meds at the moment... Mags
Posts.Title: hands, wrists and shoulders

Posts.Content: Yes, I'm guessing that they'd rather make some money (re-packaging it as a generic) than nothing at all Carol.  The clincher for me was when I looked at the leaflet in my Sandoz box and it gave the Novartis telephone number for enquiries. :-)
Posts.Title: Letrozole..... Femara brand

Posts.Content: No, they used the other side.  Thank you for that Karen, I just had a quick read. I shall carry on giving it a little massage, and hopefully will get some answers tomorrow. :-)
Posts.Title: Possible Mastitis?

Posts.Content: Thanks Karen. :-) I had the same problem when I had an op last year (stitches not dissolving), so I think I must be one of those 'lucky' people, lol! Feeling rough as rats tbh, so it will be a relief to get it looked at.  I had an MRI with contrast on Saturday, so I don't know if that could have kicked this off? Mags :-) xx
Posts.Title: Possible Mastitis?

Posts.Content: Hiya! :-) I had my WLE last October, followed by 15 days of radiotherapy in December.  I'm due for my follow-up on Thursday, but my breast became quite hot (compared to the good one) and a little painful over the weekend.   I went to see my GP yesterday (following advice from Mac Nurse) and I've been given Co-amoxiclav to be taken 3 times a day.  I asked my GP if I should massage my breast (thinking back to when I was breast feeding, many years ago), but he didn't know. Any ideas?  I'm a bit concerned, as I have had real trouble with stitches not dissolving (had to have several removed before radio, had a big 'knot' that came out mid-radio, and several more rising to the surface even over the past few weeks) and subsequent infection.  Worried now that there's something 'festering' in there.... Mags x
Posts.Title: Possible Mastitis?

Posts.Content: Hi Pinkshoe, My experience has not been anywhere as bad as yours (((hugs))), but I have had infections due to my stitches not dissolving.   It was very much 'touch and go' as to whether my radio would be delayed (I had to attend my first session to find out), but thankfully they agreed to start it and 'see how it goes', as I seemed to be healing well. I'm sure that they will get you in as soon as they possibly can, but as has already been said, the radio is more a precautionary measure, as they will have removed the 'offending lump/s', and they don't want to 'zap' delicate tissue.  For now, please just try to take it easy and let your body heal itself. :-) I was told that it could be some weeks before I get the results of my DEXA scan, but it's just to provide a 'baseline' (so that they can see if the medication affects your bone density), so nothing to worry about. My GP was very understanding when I went to see him (I was feeling very tense and anxious), and gave me some meds that I could take as and when I needed them.  They've helped enormously, and I can now concentrate on my radio and getting ready for Christmas.  May be worth a try? I hope that things improve for you soon hun, Mags :-)
Posts.Title: Post-surgery waiting for radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Lou, I'm sorry, I haven't heard of Pom before, but maybe someone else will have tried it.  Best of luck with it hun, but don't forget that if a particular brand suits you, you can ask your GP to specify it on your prescription.  Then it's just a case of calling around pharmacies until you find it. Mags :-) xx
Posts.Title: New brand of letrozole

Posts.Content: Thank you for the link Toxophilite!   I had a letter in December (following my 1 year DEXA scan), telling me that my bone density had decreased, and that I would be referred to the Metabolic Bone Clinic.  I called them in January, to be told that there could be a 3 month wait (still waiting).  Fortunately, my GP decided that the letter was justification enough for prescribing Alendronic Acid (oral, weekly).  I have to say, I was a little disturbed when the nurse that I spoke to at the clinic seemed to know nothing about biophosphonates and bone mets....if I ever get my appointment, I shall 'have a word'.... Mags
Posts.Title: Zoledronic Acid

Posts.Content: Your information about the hypothalamus is very interesting Dreamthief, thank you (I shall investigate further). I've read that Magnesium can really help with the hot flushes (just have a Google).  Mine arrived today, so I'm going to give it a try.  Mags :-) xx
Posts.Title: Too Many Hot Flushes

Posts.Content: Thank you so much Richelle.  I just gave it another bathe and there was far less 'gunk' today, so I shall try to get in to see someone tomorrow. Mags :-)
Posts.Title: Stitches not dissolving.

Posts.Content: Yes, there's a ridge of skin under my scar, which is quite red, but no sign of the stitch, so it must be fairly deep.  Thank you for that J, I shall give it a try.   I must admit, it's the one at the foot of the incision that most worries me due to the hole.  It's about 3-4mm across, and I think there's a cavity behind, it as when I put pressure on it (to clean it out) and then release it, it makes a little whistling noise!  For now I've been doing this to try to suck in some saline and then antibiotic ointment to stop it from getting infected, but I'm concerned that if it hasn't healed within the next week or so, it could cause problems during radiotherapy? Mags
Posts.Title: Stitches not dissolving.

Posts.Content: I wondered if anyone else has had this problem, or can offer me any advice?  I'm supposed to start radiotherapy in just under two weeks, and I'm really not sure what to do. I'm not sure if it's down to my body makeup, as I had the same problem after my hysterectomy earlier in the year. A couple of weeks after my op (wide local incision with nodes), I was given antibiotics and cream by my GP, as the 'foot' of the incision was slightly infected.  Three weeks later (still applying cream), the oncologist's nurse removed 5 for me but had to leave 2 in (in the vertical incision), as they were stuck firm, and she just snipped the ends off.  A couple of days ago, after a warm bath, one of these finally 'came to a head' and some 'gunk' and a large knot came out. I think I still have one at the end of the lateral incision, but it seems to be under the skin, and I now have two small holes at the foot of the incision which has had some more 'gunk' in it and I have been bathing it with saline and applying the cream. The areas are a bit red, but not swollen (which I was told could cause a problem it it threw out the markings for my radiotherapy, but I really don't know what to do?   Any help would be appreciated, Mags :-)
Posts.Title: Stitches not dissolving.

Posts.Content: I'm sorry you're going through this hun, and not having gone through chemo myself, there's not much that I can add to the above.   However, it was your mention of the differing brands of meds affecting you that caught my eye. There's a thread on here entitled 'Letrozole' (initially posted by Jaram on the 11th December), which discusses a similar issue.  I have no idea if there's a similar thread for Tamoxifen but it may be worth a read... Mags xx
Posts.Title: So Scared

Posts.Content: As the others have said, Pregabalin (Lyrica) and Gabapentin (Neurontin) can be prescribed for neuropathic pain.  Just out of curiosity, have you started on any new meds during/since radiotherapy? Mags :-) x
Posts.Title: Chronic nerve pain
